explanation: A business case captures the rationale for undertaking a change. The business case provides sufficient detail to inform and request approval without providing specific intricacies about the method and/or approach to the implementation. BABOK 10.7 Business Cases

question: What is best defined as an assessment of the effects a proposed change will have on a stakeholder or stakeholder group, project, or system.
explanation: "impact analysis: An assessment of the effects a proposed change will have on a stakeholder or stakeholder group, project, or system." BABOK Appendix A: Glossary

question: When designing a workshop, what is one of the considerations that may suggest you shouldn't do it and decide to use another method instead?

options.a: Stakeholders need a forum for meaningful collaboration
options.b: You don't have a budget for performing multiple interviews
options.c: You need to achieve agreement in a short amount of time
options.d: The potential facilitator is new in the role and is not very experienced

correct_answer: The potential facilitator is new in the role and is not very experienced
explanation: "The success of the workshop is highly dependent on the expertise of the facilitator and knowledge of the participants" 10.50 Workshops. So an inexperienced facilitator is a consideration to not run a workshop. The rest of the options describe situations when a workshop is actually a good choice.

question: When prioritizing the backlog items, Paula the Product Owner realized that a particular user story lacks details to be reviewed by the team. When she tried to figure out who the stakeholders were that requested this story or which bigger business priority it supports, she could not find this information. Which aspect of requirements management may need to be improved for this team?
explanation: Requirements traceability identifies and documents the lineage of each requirement, including its backward traceability, its forward traceability, and its relationship to other requirements. BABOK 5.1 Trace Requirements. In our case, this lineage is clearly broken.

question: Which of the following is an element of requirements verification?

options.c: Ensure requirements exhibit quality characteristics, such as being complete, consistent, feasible etc.

correct_answer: Ensure requirements exhibit quality characteristics, such as being complete, consistent, feasible etc.
explanation: The rest are elements of requirements validation. BABOK 7.3 Validate Requirements

question: Cornelius the Compliance Officer explains that the project will be affected by a lot of general regulatory requirements and contractual obligations as well as lots of business rules. Given this, what should you consider?

options.a: These seem like transition requirements, so need to treat them as such
options.b: Regulatory requirements will come from legislation, so no need to traceability matrix
options.c: These types of requirements are prime candidates for reuse. You should check if they already exist in the business to potentially save time, and if not prepare them for future reuse.
options.d: On the second thought, there is nothing unusual about these. There is no need to apply any special treatment.

correct_answer: These types of requirements are prime candidates for reuse. You should check if they already exist in the business to potentially save time, and if not prepare them for future reuse.
explanation: Requirements that are potential candidates for long-term use are those an organization must meet on an ongoing basis. Examples are regulatory, contractual obligations, business rules etc. Refer to BABOK 3.4 Plan Business Analysis Information Management

question: As a part of going live with a new solution, you and Dean the Data analyst performed a very tedious analysis: mapped all the data attributes from the old system (which will be decommissioned) to the new system, so the data can be migrated. Dean is worried that after the migration is over the work you did will not be preserved and may get forgotten or lost in the future. How would you address this situation?

options.a: Ensure all the mappings are preserved as a part of reusable requirements architecture
options.b: Include the data mapping requirements into the backlog and store together with the rest of requirements for reuse in future projects.
options.c: Ensure the data migration requirements you uncovered are a part of new team members onboarding process so the knowledge retains
options.d: Will treat the migration requirements derived from data mapping as any other requirement on the project but won't do anything specific to preserve them after the solution is live and functioning. They likely won't be needed or reused in the futre.

correct_answer: Will treat the migration requirements derived from data mapping as any other requirement on the project but won't do anything specific to preserve them after the solution is live and functioning. They likely won't be needed or reused in the futre.
explanation: Here, we are talking about transition requirements. "transition requirement: A requirement that describes the capabilities the solution must have and the conditions the solution must meet to facilitate transition from the current state to the future state, but which are not needed once the change is complete. They are differentiated from other requirements types because they are of a temporary nature." BABOK Appendix A: Glossary. As the old solution will be decommissioned, chances to reuse the requirements are very low; given their temporary nature there is no ongoing need to preserve them beyond the end of the project.

question: The following aspects will likely be placed in which quadrant of SWOT: experienced personnel, effective processes, efficient IT systems, great customer relationships
explanation: anything that the assessed group does well belongs to Strengths. 10.46 SWOT Analysis

question: Billie the Big boss requires an analysis piece that would factor in both internal and external conditions for company's strengths and weaknesses so this analysis can inform strategic prioritization of initiatives. Which technique would you use?
explanation: SWOT analysis is a simple yet effective tool used to evaluate an organization's strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats to both internal and external conditions. BABOK 10.46 SWOT Analysis

question: You have initiated a document review with a group of stakeholders. Now you see first review results: one stakeholder sent a list of recommendations to further improve the document; another sent an acknowledgement that they read it; another sent a meeting invite to discuss the document with a broader group of stakeholders. You clearly missed an important step when preparing for the review. Which one?

options.b: Define and clearly articulate the objective of the review
options.c: Select an appropriate technique for the review
options.d: This is an expected result of a review process, nothing seems to be missing

correct_answer: Define and clearly articulate the objective of the review
explanation: It seems the stakeholders thought they needed to do different things during the review. It appears the clear objectives of the review were not articulated. Refer to BABOK 10.37 Reviews

question: You need to run a scoping workshop to understand the requirements your stakeholders have for a specific product. You need to decide which techniques you want to use. Which approach will you take?

options.a: Do a research or previous projects and see which techniques were used. This way you can reuse some of the artifacts, plus the audience might be familiar with the techniques.
options.b: Explore the industry books or reach out to broader community for advice on what works best
options.c: Both are sound approaches, and even combining them might be a good idea
options.d: Neither seems like a good approacjh

correct_answer: Both are sound approaches, and even combining them might be a good idea
explanation: When selecting elicitation techniques, business analysts consider: â€¢ techniques commonly used in similar initiatives, â€¢ techniques specifically suited to the situation BABOK 4.1 Prepare for Elicitation

question: What defines the formal relationships between people working in the enterprise?
explanation: Organizational structure defines the formal relationships between people working in the enterprise. BABOK 6.1 Analyze Current State

question: You are in a brainstorming session trying to find ways to identify new areas of focus for a working group (identify potential business needs). The group has come up with the following options:

options.1: Analyze strategic goals and define business needs from them
options.2: Talk to middle managers and understand their pain points
options.a: Analyse current state of business processes
options.b: Analyse future state of the business
options.d: It is as good as it could be, there is nothing to add

correct_answer: Analyse current state of business processes
explanation: A business need may be identified at many different levels of the enterprise: 1. top-down (strategic goals) 2. bottom-up (current state of business processes, function or system) 3. middle management 4. external drivers (customer demand and business competition) BABOK 6.1 Analyze Current State

question: Pete the Process analyst needs to present a high level overview of a business process to a group of business stakeholders who have never worked with process models before. What would you recommend for Pete to do?

options.a: Use a well-defined formal notation like BPMN and send the stakeholders a shareable link to the model so they can access it
options.b: User a value stream map to indicate the process and have a conversation about it with the stakeholders so they can ask questions
options.c: Don't use any models - just create a detailed textual description of a process so they can read it.
options.d: Request for the stakeholders to attend a training course to upskill in process modelling

correct_answer: User a value stream map to indicate the process and have a conversation about it with the stakeholders so they can ask questions
explanation: Value stream mapping is the most basic and high level way to model a process, it is often used in business domain. BABOK 10.35 Process Modelling Given the situation, you want to use something simple to quickly understand and move beyond learning notation to getting value out of the model. Ability to present in person and answer questions is also preferred, as you never know which aspect of an unfamiliar tool may confuse people so better give them opportunity to discusss

question: When documenting the architecture of business, Bob the Business architect defined key business capabilities and how they can be combined and used together to deliver value to customers. He struggles however to use this view to optimise the current performance of the business. What can you recommend?

options.a: Try to build a technology infrastructure model and use it instead
options.b: Assign KPIs to capabilities and use the KPIs for optimisation
options.d: Build a process-centric view of the enterprise in addition to the capability-centric view he's got already

correct_answer: Build a process-centric view of the enterprise in addition to the capability-centric view he's got already
explanation: Business analysts may use 1. A capability-centric view of the enterprise when looking for innovative solutions that combine existing capabilities to produce a new outcome. 2. A process-centric view of the enterprise when looking for ways to improve the performance of current activities BABOK 6.1 Analyze Current State

question: The project team has finished a stage of a project and released a version of a product live. They have decided that sales numbers together with client feedback via feedback form will be used as performance measures. So, they've designed an approach to collect the data (via web analytics extract for sales figures and a feedback form for customer feedback), defined that the data will be analysed after the solution is live for at least 2 months, and after 2 months collected it. However, the results proved to be inconclusive with sales figures showing low performance and client feedback being very positive. What might be the reason for it?

options.a: They have missed an important step to validate performance measures, so likely the selected measures are not the best indicators for performance
options.b: They have missed an important step to define the timing to collect the data
options.c: They mistakenly used quantitative and qualitative data together
options.d: They did not do anything wrong, just the data needs more in depth analysis

correct_answer: They have missed an important step to validate performance measures, so likely the selected measures are not the best indicators for performance
explanation: You need to define solution performance measures, then validate the measures, then collect the measures considering volume and sample size, timeframes and currency of data. BABOK 8.1 Measure Solution Performance. In our case the team did not perform validation of the measures. Validating performance measures helps to ensure that the assessment of solution performance is useful. Non-validated measures may lead to inconclusive or erroneous results.

question: What is a good example of a qualitative measure?
explanation: Qualitative Measures: are subjective and can include attitudes, perceptions, and any other subjective response. BABOK 8.1 Measure Solution Performance. In our list only the client compliments fall into this category, the rest are quantitative.

question: The web-store your company owns uses a complicated recommendation engine that recommends products the user is likely to enjoy based on their history of purchases. The algorithm occasionally returns errors, so Pia the Process analyst is going to use process analysis technique to analyze the recommendation process. Do you think it is the best way to address the issue, and why?

options.a: Yes, process analysis is a great choice and it offers different techniques and methodologies to provide flexibility needed for this task
options.b: Yes, process analysis can be used to analyse decision making such as recommendation process
options.c: No, process analysis may prove ineffective at process improvement in knowledge or decision intensive processes such as recommending products.
options.d: No, process analysis is not a technique on its own and can't be done without in-depth process modelling.

correct_answer: No, process analysis may prove ineffective at process improvement in knowledge or decision intensive processes such as recommending products.
explanation: It may prove ineffective at process improvement in knowledge or decision intensive processes. BABOK 10.34 Process Analysis

question: The following statement describes which level of requirements: "statements of goals, objectives, and outcomes that describe why a change has been initiated"
explanation: This is "business requirement'. BABOK Guide 2.3 Requirements Classification Schema

question: In a typical organisational chart, what does a line depict?
explanation: A line depicts: Lines of Reporting: accountability and control between units. BABOK 10.32 Organizational Modelling

question: For a project that costs $100 000 to implement and that is expected to bring $120 000 of benefits, what is the ROI?
explanation: Return on Investment = (Total Benefits â€“ Cost of the Investment) / Cost of the Investment BABOK 10.20 Financial Analysis

question: The overall goal of which activity is to transform the elicitation results into requirements and designs?
explanation: It is the definition of Specify and model requirements. BABOK 7.1 Specify and Model Requirements

question: What is the best definition of solution performance measures?

options.a: Measures that provide information on how well the solution is performing or potentially could perform
options.b: Measures that provide information on which solution should be selected over alternatives
options.c: Criteria associated with a solution that must be met in order to achieve stakeholder acceptance.
options.d: An influencing factor that is believed to be true but has not been confirmed to be accurate

correct_answer: Measures that provide information on how well the solution is performing or potentially could perform
explanation: BABOK 8.1 Measure Solution Performance.

question: Your team needs a way to capture requirements, so that they capture stakeholder need, can be used as basis for estimation, as a basis for creation of acceptance tests, and as a way to measure progress. Which technique will you use?
explanation: User stories can be used (among others): â€¢ to capture stakeholder needs and prioritize development of solutions, â€¢ as a basis of estimating and planning solution delivery, â€¢ as a basis for generating user acceptance tests, â€¢ as a unit of project management and reporting. BABOK 10.48 User Stories

question: You work in a company where people find it hard to select models appropriate for the type of solution and audience, and they don't know how to illustrate that requirements and models interact and relate to each. What would they benefit from?
explanation: Business analysts use a requirements architecture to: 1) understand which models are appropriate for the domain, solution scope, and audience; 2) organize requirements into structures relevant to different stakeholders 3) illustrate how requirements and models interact with and relate to each other, and show how the parts fit together into a meaningful whole. BABOK 7.4 Define Requirements Architecture

question: Deanne the Data analyst is analysing a data set to figure out what was the distribution of service request among different types of customers. Which type of data mining is she performing?
explanation: Data mining is a general term that covers descriptive, diagnostic, and predictive techniques. Descriptive: <...> make it easier to see the patterns in a set of data, such as similarities between customers. BABOK 10.14 Data Mining

question: You've got a requirement to ensure certain security practices are implemented for the login functionality, and a separate requirement to have a logged in state. There is clearly a relationship between the two. Which type of relationship are we talking about here?

options.a: Derive: one item is derived from another
options.b: Satisfy: one of the items is an implementation of another
options.c: Dependency -> Necessity: It only makes sense to implement a requirement if another one is also implemented
options.d: Dependency -> Effort: it is easier to implement one requirement if another is also implemented

correct_answer: Dependency -> Necessity: It only makes sense to implement a requirement if another one is also implemented
explanation: Depends: relationship between two requirements, used when a requirement depends on another requirement. Types of dependency relationships include Necessity: when it only makes sense to implement a particular requirement if a related requirement is also implemented. BABOK 5.1 Trace Requirements. This is our case.

question: A very high-profile compliance project has a long list of requirements. A company can be fined for not implementing those. Unfortunately, it is obvious not all of them can be implemented in the time requested by the regulator, so prioritization needs to happen. Palash the Product Manager is prioritizing the requirements based on the financial cost-benefit ratio. You feel like there might be a better way for this situation. Which basis of prioritization would you suggest for him to use instead?

options.a: Just benefit alone, costs are not important in this case as this is compliance so requirements need to be implemented regardless of cost.
options.b: Penalty, you need to address the ones with highest regulatory penalty if not implemented first
options.c: Risk, prioritise the most uncertain ones first so you know which ones can or cannot be met at all
options.d: Stability, prioritise those that are less likely to change over time

correct_answer: Penalty, you need to address the ones with highest regulatory penalty if not implemented first
explanation: All of these are sound bases for prioritization, but in case of a regulatory request that you know you can't fulfill on time the penalty in unavoidable. So the best strategy may be to try decrease this penalty. Refer to BABOK 5.3 Prioritize Requirements for more details on different prioritization approaches.

question: What is best defined as an act of transformation in response to a need?
explanation: "change: The act of transformation in response to a need." BABOK Appendix A: Glossary

question: When planning a project, you realise that the corresponding legislation will change during the course of the project, and the new law is already approved and is waiting to come into force on a pre-defined date. How will you treat it?

options.a: As a risk; it is an unfortunate event that will need to be dealt with.
options.b: As an assumption; and will address when it happens
options.c: As a requirement; so the solution is built accommodating for the new legislation by design
options.d: As an unknown; you can't be sure what does it mean for you yet

correct_answer: As a requirement; so the solution is built accommodating for the new legislation by design
explanation: When dealing with risks, there is uncertainty in the likelihood of it occurring, and the impact if it does occur. When dealing with assumption, you don't know if it is true or not. In our case, both definitions can not be applied, so it is a straightforward legal requirement.

question: What is used to record, track, and prioritize remaining work items?
explanation: The backlog is used to record, track, and prioritize remaining work items. BABOK 10.2 Backlog Management

question: After having performed solution evaluation and assessment of limitations, Billie the BA comes to a conclusion that no further actions are needed. What is the most likely result of her analysis?

options.a: She has identified extra capabilities that the system is missing
options.b: She has identified that value to implement any further changes is low relative to effort
options.c: She has identified that the solution is no longer relevant
options.d: She probably didn't do a good job - "do nothing" is not a valid strategy

correct_answer: She has identified that value to implement any further changes is low relative to effort
explanation: Based on the solution evaluation and assessment of limitation, a BA may recommend actions to further improve quality/increase value. "Do nothing" is a strategy to choose if value is low relative to effort. BABOK 8.5 Recommend Actions to Increase Solution Value

question: You have a list of requirements recorded in a Jira backlog. You discuss them one by one with your stakeholders to ensure they are agreed upon and approved. Which one of the listed below is the best way to track the fact a requirement is approved?

options.a: In meeting notes that you will send as an email
options.d: Using a shared document like a wiki page or google doc

explanation: "The business analyst records approval decisions, possibly in requirements maintenance and tracking tools." BABOK 5.5 Approve Requirements

question: What do you need to do to ensure that the right subject matter experts (SMEs) and other stakeholders are participating in the initiative effectively?

options.a: Continuously monitor the participation and performance of stakeholders and make adjustments accordingly
options.b: Create a RACI at the start of the project
options.d: Ask project manager to manage communications

correct_answer: Continuously monitor the participation and performance of stakeholders and make adjustments accordingly
explanation: Business analysts monitor the participation and performance of stakeholders to ensure that the right subject matter experts (SMEs) and other stakeholders are participating effectively. BABOK 4.5 Manage Stakeholder Collaboration

question: Benchmark studies are conducted to compare organizational practices against what?
explanation: Benchmark studies are conducted to compare organizational practices against the best-in-class practices. 10.4 Benchmarking and Market Analysis

question: b.Enterprise Limitations
explanation: Based on the solution evaluation and assessment of limitation, a BA may recommend actions to further improve quality/increase value. refer to BABOK 8.5 Recommend Actions to Increase Solution Value

question: What can be defined as a set of conventions that define how requirements will be represented, how these representations will be organized, and how they will be related to address concerns of a given stakeholder group?

options.Explanatio:A viewpoint is a set of conve: Viewpoints provide templates for addressing the concerns of particular stakeholder groups. BABOK 7.4 Define Requirements Architecture

question: The business team managed to prioritise the requirements based on expected business value. When the technical team picks the project up, they propose to reorder some requirements to ease implementation approach, promising to still deliver the full scope in initially agreed timeframes. Is it an acceptable approach?

options.a: No, the technical team cannot overrule the business prioritisation
options.b: No, you should never use ease of implementation as a factor for prioritisation
options.c: Yes, business priorities are always indicative until technical analysis is done
options.d: Yes, the basis for prioritization may be different at various stages of the change.

correct_answer: Yes, the basis for prioritization may be different at various stages of the change.
explanation: The basis for prioritization may be different at various stages of the change. For example, stakeholders may initially prioritize based on benefits. The implementation team may then re-prioritize the requirements based on the sequence in which they must be implemented due to technical constraints. BABOK 5.3 Prioritize Requirements

question: After you've understood the problem at hand and listed the requirements to the solution, you tell your manager you want to spend time defining solution options. Your manager is not convinced it is needed because they already have a change strategy in place. How do you respond?

options.b: Solution options is an integral part of project management best practices so must be done
options.c: When designing a solution, there may be one and only one design option and it needs to be identified
options.d: Design options exist at a lower level than the change strategy, and are tactical rather than strategic

correct_answer: Design options exist at a lower level than the change strategy, and are tactical rather than strategic
explanation: When designing a solution, there may be one or more design options identified. Each design option represents a way to satisfy a set of requirements. Design options exist at a lower level than the change strategy, and are tactical rather than strategic. BABOK 7.5 Define Design Options

question: Billie the Big boss (and the project sponsor at the same time) tells the team one day: "We don't have enough time, so let's skip working on transition requirements. Anyway they are of temporary nature so not that important." What will be your response?

options.a: Billie is right, they are of temporary nature so can be omitted.
options.b: Transition requirements are temporary in nature indeed, but they are needed to facilitate the transition from the current state to the future state and as such are important.
options.c: Transition requirements are not temporary and have to be defined for the years to come.
options.d: Even though they are of temporary nature, transition requirements are an important part of non-functional requirements and can't be omitted.

correct_answer: Transition requirements are temporary in nature indeed, but they are needed to facilitate the transition from the current state to the future state and as such are important.
explanation: "describe the capabilities that the solution must have and the conditions the solution must meet to facilitate transition from the current state to the future state, but which are not needed once the change is complete. They are differentiated from other requirements types because they are of a temporary nature." 2.3 Requirements Classification Schema

question: Your project is almost done, the technical solution is developed and fully tested and will be launched to production soon. In order to ensure smooth transition to the new solution, you are assessing current business process, policies, team members' skills and other tools they use to identify any potential gaps or conflicts so you can resolve them before going live. In other words, which assessment do you perform?
explanation: The operational assessment is performed to determine if an enterprise is able to adapt to or effectively use a solution. This identifies which processes and tools within the enterprise are adequately equipped to benefit from the solution, and if sufficient and appropriate assets are in place to support it. When conducting an operational assessment, business analysts consider: â€¢ policies and procedures, â€¢ capabilities and processes that enable other capabilities, â€¢ skill and training needs, â€¢ human resources practices, â€¢ risk tolerance and management approaches, and â€¢ tools and technology that support a solution. BABOK 8.3 Assess Solution Limitations

question: Working on a project, Bill the Business Analyst needs to collect a lot of data about different items stored in the company's warehouse. This is done so the data can be analysed and a proper automation system can be put in place to manage stock. Which modelling format would you recommend for Bill to use?
explanation: A Matrix is better suited for this case. "a matrix is used when the business analyst is modelling a requirement or set of requirements that have a complex but uniform structure, which can be broken down into elements that apply to every entry in the table." BABOK 7.1 Specify and Model Requirements

question: Although requirements attributes can be defined specifically for your project, some of them tend to be commonly used. Which attribute is typically used to provide a unique identifier for a requirement?
explanation: Absolute reference: provides a unique identifier. The reference is not altered or reused if the requirement is moved, changed, or deleted. Refer to BABOK 3.4 Plan Business Analysis Information Management

question: Sue the Stakeholder approaches you and asks to implement a new feature for her department. The feature seems reasonable, however it has not been prioritised for your team to work on yet, and you know that chances are it won't be prioritised in foreseeable future due to high priority work items on your yearly roadmap. What do you do?

options.a: In the spirit of agile, treat it as customer feedback and accept it to work as soon as you can.
options.b: Reject it as there no room to look into it
options.c: Do not promise anything but add it to the backlog to be looked at during the next backlog refinement opportunity
options.d: Escalate the issue to the board for decision making

correct_answer: Do not promise anything but add it to the backlog to be looked at during the next backlog refinement opportunity
explanation: Backlog is your record of all work that is not done yet. So customer/stakeholder requests should be recorded there so they can be prioritised alongside other work items. Then according to BABOK "Periodic review of the entire backlog should occur because changes in stakeholder needs and priorities may necessitate changes to the priority of some of the backlog items. In many environments, the backlog is reviewed at planned intervals." BABOK 10.2 Backlog Management. This way answer 3 seems the best course of action.

question: Which out of the following issues can be resolved using traceability?

options.A: Perform impact analysis when a requirement changes
options.B: Perform assessment which requirements are covered by test cases
options.C: Clearly articulate end to end solution implementation approach
options.D: Discover inconsistencies and gaps in requirements

explanation: Refer to BABOK 5.1 Trace Requirements
